journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Post-impact residual high strain rate compressive properties of carbon fiber laminates

article-meta.aff: Composite Materials and Mechanics Laboratory, Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Polytechnic Institute of New York University, Brooklyn, NY, USA

author-notes.corresp: Nikhil Gupta, Composite Materials and Mechanics Laboratory, Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Polytechnic Institute of New York University, Brooklyn, NY 11201, USA. Email: ngupta@poly.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The purpose of the present study is to investigate the residual high strain rate compressive properties of cross-ply carbon fiber laminates after drop-weight impact. The tested laminate is divided into four quadrants and specimens are extracted from each quadrant for high strain rate compression testing using a split–Hopkinson pressure bar. The testing is conducted in the strain rate range of 1000–1450 s−1. A comparison between pre- and post-impact carbon fiber laminates subjected to high strain rate compression suggested that there is a maximum decrease of 76.1% and 71.6% in the peak stress and absorbed energy of the laminate, respectively, at high strain rate compression. Microscopy was conducted on the failed specimens to determine the failure mode. Extensive delamination observed at the impact point causes significant decrease in compressive strength and energy absorption of the laminate.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Carbon fiber laminates have high rigidity coupled with low relative density. Their applications are geared towards wind turbine blades, automobile panels, and aircraft parts including helicopter blades and aircraft wings. Carbon fiber laminates are now extensively used in aircraft structures. The damage tolerance and post-impact residual properties of such composites, especially under low-velocity impact, remain as significant concerns.1

Delamination is a mode of failure in laminates, which can lead to significant reduction in compressive strength. Delamination due to impact may have multiple causes, for example, fiber misorientation, internal flaws, or defects induced during material processing.2–4 The defects and flaws may be present inside the laminate and may not be visible on the surface. Ultrasonic imaging is used in past studies on characterizing fracture and delamination modes of cross-ply laminates.5–7 It is possible to view defects in a material along the depth and across a plane of interest using ultrasonic C-scan technique.8 Therefore, structural assessments can be made when observing the origin of internal damage with respect to the fiber orientation in a laminate.

Residual properties of laminates after impact have been of great interest in the past studies. A large body of literature is available that focuses on various aspects of this issue. However, most of the published studies deal with quasi-static residual properties. The present work is aimed at studying the high strain rate (HSR) compressive behavior of post-impact carbon fiber laminate. A brief description of the available literature is presented next to establish the scope of the present work.

Compression-after-impact (CAI) analysis of composite laminates is useful because automobile and aircraft structures may be impacted by hail, rocks, abrasive debris, birds or animals, and tools being dropped during maintenance, all of which can affect the compressive strength of the laminate.9,10 Several experimental and numerical studies have been conducted on the CAI properties of fiber-reinforced laminates.9,11–13 Experimental studies have assessed the variation of compressive strength and energy absorption in laminates with respect to orientation and alignment of fibers, variation in temperature, variation in tup crosshead velocity, and presence of flaws or delamination.6,11,14–19 Effect of in-plane or out-of-plane loading directions and the fiber weave orientation, diameter, and spacing have been characterized in these studies. Comparisons between experimental results and finite element analysis of material impact have been conducted for further inquiry into the strength and energy absorption parameters of laminates.13,20–23

Quasi-static compression has been performed to determine the residual mechanical properties of fiber-reinforced laminates in CAI analysis, and comparisons have been made to analytical models.9,24 Quasi-static compression studies of fiber-reinforced laminates are abundant in literature.7,25–27 The mechanism for in-plane compressive failure is generally caused by delamination, which is induced by buckling and separation of layers and fibers under quasi-static and HSR regimes.22,25,28 Studies have also demonstrated variation in strength and stiffness in terms of out-of-plane loading, where unidirectional and cross-ply carbon fiber laminates have been impacted in the out-of-plane direction.29,30 Despite the stable configuration of the laminate and its layers, out-of-plane loading has been deemed likely to lead to splitting of the laminate layers, which can degrade the laminate strength.29 The influence of HSR compression on the out-of-plane CAI properties of laminates remains to be assessed.

For the present study, pre- and post-impact ultrasonic C-scans are taken of the carbon fiber laminates to observe the extent of the low-velocity impact damage. Specimens are extracted from the laminate and characterized for HSR compression using a split–Hopkinson pressure bar (SHPB). The mechanical properties of the tested laminate are quantified with respect to the distance from the impact point to observe variations in HSR strength and energy absorption. The results are compared with control specimens extracted from an identical carbon fiber laminate that has not been subjected to impact. The present study can be useful in understanding the behavior of composite laminates under HSR compression, which is relevant to structures in the automotive and aerospace industries.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: A 0–90° cross-ply carbon fiber laminate obtained from Graph Tech R/C (Cypress, TX) is used for this study. Plate-like specimens of 75 mm in length and width are impacted in the out-of-plane direction. The pre- and post-impact conditions of the laminates are assessed using a Physical Acoustics ULTRAPAC (Princeton Jct., NJ) water immersion type ultrasonic C-scan system to identify the location and extent of damage. The testing is conducted in pulse-echo mode using a 5 MHz transducer. Time-of-flight (ToF) and amplitude data are collected during ultrasonic imaging.

The impact tests are conducted using an Instron Dynatup 8200 instrumented drop-weight impact tower equipped with a hemispherical tup, which follows the ASTM D7136 standard.31 If the laminate does not fracture, then the rebound of the drop weight crosshead is arrested using air brakes to avoid multiple impacts on the test specimen. Load and tup velocity data are collected during the test. The impact energy,Ei, is calculated by (1)Ei=mvi22 where m is the mass of the impactor and vi is the tup velocity at impact. The 4.96 kg impactor was raised to a height of 72.4 cm, which provided a maximum velocity of 3.19 m s−1. The impact energy, calculated by equation (1), was found to be 25.2 J.

The detailed procedure of SHPB testing is available in a previous publication.32 Incident, reflected, and transmitted strain wave signals are collected during the test and are used to develop the stress–strain graphs. All the tests were conducted at the same striker bar launch pressure but small differences in the specimen dimensions can result in different strain rates. Therefore, actual strain rate values are recovered from the tests and are reported with the results.

A Nikon D7000 digital SLR camera with AF-S VR Micro-Nikkor 105 mm f/2.8G IF-ED telephoto lens was used for image acquisition of the specimens after HSR compression. This macro lens is capable of taking high-resolution images of small objects with high depth of focus.
Hitachi 3400N variable pressure scanning electron microscope (SEM) is used for failure analysis. The specimens are sputter-coated with a conductive layer of gold before microscopy.

The test scheme adopted in the present work is described as follows. The laminate is first scanned using ultrasonic C-scan system to ensure that there are no measurable internal defects and then impacted at the center with the drop weight setup. The impacted laminate is again scanned using C-scan system to determine the extent of damage. Specimens are cut from the impacted laminate for HSR compression testing as per the scheme shown in Figure 1. The specimens have square cross-section of 10 × 10 mm2. The specimens obtained at the same distance from the impact point from different quadrant are expected to show similar behavior. HSR compression behavior of the laminate was also tested without the impact, which is termed as the control laminate. The results of the control and post-impact laminates are compared to determine the difference in the residual HSR compression properties. The nomenclature of the HSR compression test specimens is shown in Figure 1. The average thickness of the HSR specimens was nearly constant within each set of specimens tested (6.3 mm for impacted, 5.9 mm for non-impacted), with thickness variation measured to be less than 5% for all specimens. Figure 1.
Representation of locations where compression test specimens were recovered from the impacted carbon fiber laminate. The point where the low-velocity tup impacted the plate is marked as “0”.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
A representative C-scan image of the untested laminate is shown in Figure 2. The color coding scale on the left side of Figure 2 denotes the range of relative peak amplitude percentages detected across the laminate. The system was able to capture the alternating weave patterns inside of the laminate plate, denoted by the evenly distributed variation in colors between 25% and 50% peak amplitude. Uniformity in the amplitude map demonstrates good laminate quality. In the next step, the laminates are subjected to impact testing. Figure 2.
Ultrasonic C-scan map of carbon fiber laminate before impact.

sec.title: Impact testing
sec.p:
The load and deflection obtained from the test are plotted with respect to time in Figure 3(a). During impact, the laminate experienced a maximum of 7.5 kN of load and 5.0 mm of deflection according to the graphs. The profile of the load-time graph shows a trend similar to that observed in previous studies, where fluctuations in load are observed at the peak and are generally indicative of delamination.9 Similar fluctuations are not observed for the deflection curve, which is calculated from both the velocity signal and double integration of the load signal over time as described in ASTM D7136.31 The specimen was not penetrated under impact. This is also evident due to the fact that the load and deflection graphs decrease to zero after the duration of contact, which was estimated to be about 6 ms. However, damage to the plate was induced, leading to fluctuations near the maximum load, as observed in Figure 3(a). The absorbed energy, Ea, with respect to time t is expressed using the following equation given in ASTM D7136: (2)Ea(t)=m(vi2-v(t)2)2+mgδ(t) where m is the mass of the impactor, vi is the impact velocity, v is the impactor velocity at time t, g is acceleration due to gravity, and δ is the deflection at time t.31 Equation (2) is plotted in Figure 3(b) with respect to time. During service use, material panels under impact may not completely fracture and may or may not show any sign of damage on the surface. In this case, slight surface damage was observed, and a loss of absorbed energy due to localized material failure is evidenced in Figure 3(b), where the absorbed energy levels off at a value of 16.3 J. The post-impact assessment is focused on visualizing the impact damage and determining its effect on the residual HSR compressive properties. Figure 3.
(a) Load and deflection graphs with respect to time and (b) cumulative energy graph with respect to time of laminate impacted by Instron dynatup drop weight setup.

sec.title: Post-impact damage assessment
sec.p:
A second C-scan of the laminate is taken for damage assessment after impact, as shown in Figure 4. In this case, ToF of the ultrasonic pulse is used to observe the damage location and extent. The impact zone and the damage propagation can clearly be seen in this figure, covering a maximum distance of ∼10 mm along the horizontal direction and ∼14 mm along the vertical. No severe damage can be seen in other sections of the plate. The spread of the damage observed in this image depends on the threshold settings used in the imaging and the frequency of ultrasound used in the scan. Although there is no visible damage to the plate, the internal damage that is detected by ultrasonic imaging is expected to affect the mechanical properties and failure mechanism of the laminate. Figure 4.
Ultrasonic C-scan image of post-impact laminate showing a damage zone at the center of the specimen.

sec.title: HSR compression characterization
sec.p: The SHPB testing provides incident, reflected, and transmitted strain waves, which are converted into the stress–strain information for the specimen. Data from the strain wave signals obtained from the bars are used to obtain the stress at the incident bar-specimen and specimen-transmitted bar interfaces. The forces at the two interfaces (P1 and P2) are evaluated as: (3)P1=EAb(ɛi+ɛr) (4)P2=EAbɛt where Ab and E represent the cross-sectional area and elastic modulus of the bar, respectively, and ɛi, ɛr, and ɛt represent the incident, reflected, and transmitted strain, respectively. If the stress equilibrium is achieved in the specimen during deformation, then the forces represented by equations (3) and (4) must be equal and the following relation can be derived: (5)ɛi+ɛr=ɛt

A representative set of result presented in Figure 5 shows that stress equilibrium is reached in the specimen during SHPB testing. The coinciding stress pulses on the front and back surface demonstrate stress equilibrium in the specimens during SHPB testing. Figure 5.
Stress equilibrium in a post-impact laminate specimen during high strain rate compression testing.

The HSR compression test results for the control laminate are plotted in Figure 6. Peak stress and energy absorption are represented in Figure 6(a) and (b), respectively. The peak stress values are consistent and do not show measurable strain rate sensitivity in the given specimen type and test orientation within the narrow strain rate range of 1000–1450 s−1. Despite having the stress values in a narrow band, the energy values show considerable fluctuations due to the large variations in the failure strain of the specimens. Figure 6.
(a) Peak stress and (b) absorbed energy of non-impacted carbon fiber laminate with respect to strain rate.

The HSR compression results for the post-impact laminate are presented in Figure 7. The peak stress values shown in Figure 6 for the control specimens are marked as a reference band for comparison in Figure 7(a). For the specimens obtained from the impacted plate, the peak stress values monotonically increase and reach the reference band after a distance of around 30 mm away from the point of impact. This implies that the impact damage is induced in the laminate farther than that observed in the C-scan results seen in Figure 2. The peak stress values are very consistent for the specimens obtained from different quadrants, except for one case. This illustrates that the damage propagation is symmetric in the laminate. The energy absorption values are presented in Figure 7(b). Similar to the control specimen, the standard deviation is large for the energy absorption values. The general trend shows an increase in energy absorption with increasing distance from the impact point. When comparing all specimens extracted from both plates, a maximum decrease of 76.1% and 71.6% in the peak stress and the absorbed energy, respectively, can be observed. The maximum decrease in strength and energy were observed at the impact point of the laminate, where most of the damage was located. Note that these values are dependent on the impact parameters and fiber orientation with respect to the HSR compression axis. Figure 7.
(a) Peak stress and (b) energy absorption at high strain rate compression for carbon fiber laminate specimens plotted with respect to distance from the impact point. The rectangular region in (a) represents the values obtained for the non-impacted laminate, shown in Figure 6(a).

Failure analysis is conducted on the control and the post-impact specimens subjected to HSR compression. Figure 8 shows the failure features of the specimen across the laminate in one quadrant to observe the effect of existing impact damage on the compression failure mode. Impact caused significant delamination in the laminate and subsequent compression resulted in specimen cracking. The effect of delamination decreases with the distance from the impact location. The failure features of a control specimen subjected to HSR compression can be observed in Figure 9. All specimens of the control laminate show the same kind of failure, where shear cracks dominate. The post-impact HSR compression failure of specimens B-3 and B-4 is similar to that of the control specimen because the impact damage was very small at these locations. Figure 8.
Post-impact high strain rate compression failure features of the laminated specimens extracted across quadrant B. Significant delamination is observed in the first two specimens, while shear failure features dominate the last three specimens. Thick arrows in specimen “0” represent direction of high strain rate (HSR) compression.
Figure 9.
Failure mode in a specimen obtained from the control laminate. Shear failure is observed in this specimen.

SEM images were taken at the center point of the impacted and control laminates after HSR compression. Shear cracks in the control laminate do not cause fiber crushing as observed in Figure 10. It can be observed that the matrix failed under HSR compression. The fiber-matrix interfacial bonding appears to be very good in the laminates. In contrast, the impacted specimen clearly demonstrates delamination in several layers of the composite as observed in Figure 11. Existence of multiple cracks and fiber breakage due to the combined effect of impact and HSR compression can be found as the failure features in the figure. Figure 10.
Scanning electron micrograph of a control laminate specimen that is high strain rate (HSR) compression tested at 1330 s−1. Shear crack propagation through fiber layers can be seen in (a), and good fiber-matrix adhesion can be observed in (b).
Figure 11.
Post-impact carbon fiber laminate, where laminae oriented along different directions are being separated in (a), along with extensive fraying of fibers. The specimen was taken from the midpoint (Specimen 0 in Figure 1) of the impacted slab and tested at a strain rate of 1530 s−1. Delamination in an outer layer of the composite is observed in (b), where the inset clearly denotes layer separation occurring perpendicular to the direction of loading.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
Post-impact HSR compression of a carbon fiber laminate was studied in the present work. Ultrasonic C-scans was used for identifying the internal damage in the laminate due to impact. A control laminate was also tested for HSR compression to compare the results obtained on the impact-tested laminate. The following conclusions were drawn from the results:
Internal damage can be visualized on the impacted plate using ultrasonic C-scan analysis after drop-weight impact testing. The damage is observed to spread in a range of about 14 mm from the center with a maximum impact load of 7.5 kN under the selected impact conditions.
A maximum decrease of 76.1 and 71.6% can be seen for the peak stress and the absorbed energy, respectively, of the carbon fiber laminate specimens tested under HSR compression with respect to the control specimen.
Impact damage occurs in the form of delamination in the present low-velocity impact test. HSR compression test specimens show delamination and fiber crushing as the failure features. The failure away from the impact location occurs in the form of shear cracks across the laminate thickness. The control laminate also shows the same kind of failure mechanism.

The results of the present study demonstrate that the low-velocity impact and HSR compressive loading behavior may be relevant for structural designs that use carbon fiber laminates. Propagation of damage in automobiles and aircraft made of composites can benefit from considerations discussed in this study. Future studies may be focused on characterizing the in-plane HSR compression behavior with respect to the fiber orientation in the laminate.

ack.p: The authors thank the MAE Department for providing facilities and support and Dr. Dinesh Pinisetty for helping in manuscript preparation.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study was supported by the Office of Naval Research grant N00014-10-1-0988 with Dr. Yapa D. S. Rajapakse as the program manager.
